content: How can I help you today?

Well, I guess I'm here because my wife pushed me to come. Things at home have been tough—our son has been having a lot of issues, and it’s affecting everything. I honestly don’t know where to even start.
It sounds like there's been a lot going on at home, and it's weighing on you. Thank you for being open about this—it’s not easy to talk about. How has all of this been affecting you personally?

Honestly, it’s been overwhelming. I can’t focus at work, and I don’t really feel like doing anything enjoyable anymore. It’s like everything revolves around trying to figure out what’s wrong with my son and at the same time, my marriage feels like it’s falling apart.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot right now—the stress of work, concerns about your son, and the strain on your marriage. That sounds really heavy. How are you managing to cope with all of that pressure at the moment?
Honestly, I’m not sure I am managing. I feel like I just go through the motions every day, but I’m not really present. It’s like I’m stuck in this cycle, and I don’t know how to break out of it.

Feeling stuck in that kind of cycle can be incredibly exhausting and discouraging. It’s clear that you care deeply about your family, and it sounds like you're trying to hold everything together. What do you wish felt different in your life right now?

I wish I could feel like I was making progress—like I was doing something that actually helped my son or saved my marriage. It just feels like I’m failing on all fronts, and I don’t know where to even begin fixing it.

It sounds like you're longing for a sense of progress, and right now, it feels like no matter how much you care or try, it’s not leading to the changes you want. That sounds like such a hard place to be. What do you think has been keeping you from seeing that progress so far?

I think it’s just that everything feels so overwhelming—I don’t know where to focus or what to tackle first. And honestly, my wife and I aren’t always on the same page about what’s best for our son, so that makes things even harder. It’s like we’re both trying, but we’re not moving in the same direction.

It sounds like the weight of everything has left you unsure where to start, and the disconnect with your wife adds to that feeling of being stuck. Both of you care and are trying, but it’s hard to find common ground amid all the stress. What do you feel would help you move forward, even just a little, in this situation?

I don’t have a clear answer. Maybe if my wife and I could figure out how to be more of a team, that might help. Or if I could actually understand what my son needs, you know? But I honestly don’t even know where to start with any of that.

It sounds like you really want to reconnect with your wife as partners and find a way to truly understand your son’s needs. That’s a lot to navigate, but it’s clear that you care deeply about making things better. What could be a small first step toward creating that sense of teamwork or understanding?

Maybe starting with a conversation with my wife about how we can work together better could help, but I’m worried it will just turn into more arguments. Or maybe finding someone who can actually help us understand what’s going on with our son—I just don’t know where to look. Everything feels like a gamble right now.

It sounds like you’re thinking about two meaningful steps—having an open conversation with your wife and finding support to better understand your son. But the fear of arguments and uncertainty about where to turn are holding you back. These are important steps you're considering. What do you think might help you feel more confident or supported in taking one of them?

I think if my wife and I could somehow talk calmly without it turning into a fight, that would make a big difference. Maybe even having a counselor or someone mediate could help, but I’m hesitant to start that process—it feels daunting. I guess if we could find the right kind of support for our son, that might ease some of the tension too.

It sounds like having a calm and productive conversation with your wife is really important to you, and the idea of a mediator, like a counselor, feels like it could help—though it's understandable that starting that process feels overwhelming. At the same time, finding the right support for your son seems like it might ease some of the overall stress. What’s one small thing you feel ready—or almost ready—to explore in either direction, just to see what’s possible?

I guess I could look into finding someone who could help us with our son. Maybe just starting by asking around or researching therapists for him online. It feels like a lot, but I know we need to do something.

That sounds like a thoughtful and proactive step—starting to explore options for support for your son. Even just gathering some information is a step toward clarity, and it could help you feel like you’re building some momentum. How do you think taking this first step might impact things for you or your family?

Maybe if I take this step, it could help us feel like we’re not so lost—like we’re actually trying something new. And if it works, maybe it could take some pressure off my wife and me, or at least make us feel like we’re moving in the same direction. It’s just hard to know if it’ll work, but I guess it’s worth trying.

Taking that step could bring a sense of direction and hope, even if it’s just the beginning. It’s understandable to feel unsure about the outcome, but your willingness to try shows how much you care about your family. Would it help to focus on one small and manageable action today, like starting some research or asking someone for recommendations?
